title: Erdős Problem #21: Covering Intersecting Families
description: Let f(n) be minimal such that there is an intersecting family of n-sets covering all (n-1)-sets. Is f(n) = O(n)?

overview.historicalContext: Conjectured by Erdős and Lovász in 1975. They proved (8/3)n - 3 ≤ f(n) ≤ O(n^(3/2) log n). Kahn improved the upper bound to n log n in 1992, then proved the linear bound f(n) = O(n) in 1994, resolving the conjecture.
overview.problemStatement: Let $f(n)$ be minimal such that there exists an intersecting family $\mathcal{F}$ of $n$-sets with $|\mathcal{F}| = f(n)$ such that every set $S$ with $|S| \leq n-1$ is disjoint from at least one $A \in \mathcal{F}$. Is $f(n) = O(n)$?
overview.proofStrategy: Kahn's 1994 proof uses probabilistic selection from projective planes: (1) Take a projective plane of order n-1 (when n-1 is a prime power), (2) Randomly select lines, (3) Show that with positive probability O(n) lines suffice to cover all (n-1)-sets.
keyInsights: An intersecting family has all pairs sharing at least one element
The covering condition forces the family to be 'spread out'
Projective planes provide optimal constructions when n-1 is a prime power
The exact constant is conjectured to be 3 (i.e., f(n) = 3n + O(1))

conclusion.summary: Kahn (1994) proved f(n) = O(n), resolving the Erdős-Lovász conjecture. The exact bound is conjectured to be f(n) = 3n + O(1), but the gap between the lower bound (8/3)n and this conjecture remains open.
conclusion.implications: The solution demonstrates the power of probabilistic methods in combinatorics and connects intersecting families to projective geometry.
openQuestions: Determine the exact leading constant: is f(n) = 3n + O(1)?
Prove or disprove f(n) ≤ 3n for all n
